hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?
I hear analog photography still survives in your hands.

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah. City’s chaotic lately.
Couldn’t even focus on my hobby—folding paper shapes.
Kept it simple. Nothing complicated tonight.
Too many changes, you know.
Pretty rough. System’s got everyone jumpy lately.
I do origami in the evenings—helps clear my head.
Last night, papers just felt wrong.
Hard to make something structured when everything outside’s upside down.
It’s exhausting. Can’t remember when Stenograd felt stable.
I usually fold intricate origami models at home.
Folding helps me feel… orderly, when things are turbulent.
But since the ghosts showed up, can’t focus on precision folds.
Mistakes creep in, hands don’t cooperate.
Feels like my hobby’s reflecting the city’s mood.
Honestly, it’s been overwhelming. That glitch in the system—people reappearing, all the unrest.
Origami is my thing. Complex models from scrap paper.
Lately, I keep messing up the folds, corners never quite align.
I usually lose myself in the rhythm; now, I can’t get through even one crane.
They say art reflects life—I guess my messy stack proves it.
Before, I folded to escape control. Now, it just reminds me.
Even tried retracing someone else’s folds—felt like eavesdropping on a secret.
The city feels like its own failed origami right now—crumpled, then forced flat.
I started origami years back—precision, repetition, that sense of completion.
Most nights, it kept my mind straight. Used to do modular pieces, sometimes ninety folds just for one model.
After the data leak, everything’s off—paper feels heavy, mistakes build up fast.
The flyer I found? Folded by someone who ‘vanished’—strange creases, not random.
Spent hours unfolding, tracking lines. Couldn’t focus on my own patterns.
Kind of obsessed about whether their folds told a story, or a warning.
Origami isn’t just a habit anymore. It’s become the only way I still feel… present.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Cranes. Kept it simple this week.
Harder to focus with all the disruptions lately.
Paper feels thin, unreliable. Like the city right now.
Too many people watching these days.
I just fold and keep to myself.
Yeah, a couple cranes. Routine, you know.
Normally helps me unwind after work.
Been strange lately—noise in the halls, weird power outages.
Paper's all recycled now, less structure. Makes sharp folds tricky.
Saw someone using old flyers. That felt odd.
Can't really relax into it anymore.
I have, actually. Made a few last night.
Origami's sort of my anchor—calms me down when things get messy.
Lately, it feels different. The atmosphere is tense.
Folding is harder with all the talk about the ‘ghosts’ returning.
People keep leaving notes, folded up like cranes. Some carry protest slogans.
The paper's rarely clean now; it all carries something from outside.
Sometimes I wonder if any shape will hold, the way things are.
Yeah, still making cranes—though they look rougher with all this going on.
Folding used to mean control. I’d experiment with modular shapes, tessellations.
Now, my hands hesitate. It's constant noise: sirens, rumors, missing people.
I found a crane yesterday made from a BCI flyer—someone scared, maybe reaching out.
Strange, seeing protest and fear folded into something meant for peace.
Paper's scarce now too. I use scraps, receipts, even ration slips.
Feels symbolic—making order out of city chaos, or trying to.
Wish the world was as easy to unfold and start again.
Yes, still making cranes. It's all that keeps my mind from spiraling lately.
I started folding as a kid when my mother disappeared—helped bring a sense of order.
Now it feels like Stenograd itself: creased, tense, about to tear.
The city’s filled with ghosts, and I use whatever paper I can scavenge—protest flyers, compliance notices.
Sometimes I trace old creases, trying to restore something lost.
Every time the system shakes—like after Halden's death—my hands just shake, too.
My cranes end up uneven, edges jagged. Like they know things aren't right.
I miss the days when folding meant peace, not distraction from fear.
But I keep folding, even if the shapes don’t hold as long as they used to.
